We very rarely get more than 12‚Äù of accumulation on the ground here in Northern Kentucky.

99%+ of our electricity is solar. (The remaining fraction is from a propane backup generator which is very infrequently needed.) Most of our heat comes from a wood gasification boiler.  Some of our hot water, the stove, and the clothes dryer, are propane. Pizza oven is wood.

There is no special tax to pay in the state where I live if you are off grid.  Yes you could connect to the grid and sell power back to them, but typically not for the same price the company sells it to you.
Yes, about three feet in, because the wind loads are astounding.

So only about 25% (4.2kW) of my panels are immune from accumulated snow, but that‚Äôs often enough to keep things going until the snow melts here in Kentucky. I‚Äôve also been contemplating adding some dedicated East and West facing panels to extend the solar day about 2 hours.

Two years, no rust so far. I‚Äôm most concerned about the legs poured in the concrete, but 9 months out of the year, the panels keep the rain off.
